title: Templer Way Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Templer Way
images.caption: View of the trail near Brimley. The Way, following the Haytor granite tramway, within sight of the eastern edge of Yarner Wood, with gorse and pines on the slopes of Lower Down.

images.title: David Smith / Bridge on Templer Way
images.caption: Bridge on Templer Way. The Way is following the route of the carriage drive to the residence of the Templers, now Stover School. This bridge crossed one of the landscaped lakes, now dried up.

images.title: Derek Harper / Duckboards, Templer Way
images.caption: These duckboards take the Templer Way across the point where a drain from the Teign floodplain meets the disused Stover canal.

images.title: David Smith / Bridge on Templer Way
images.caption: This bridge carried the carriage drive to Stover House. The post in front is one of the markers for the Ted Hughes Trail and the plaque has one of his poems.

images.title: Derek Harper / Reed beds by the Templer Way
images.caption: Reed beds by the Way. A large pond is beyond the reed beds, although its size seems to have shrunk in recent years. On the far slope is part of the Orleigh development north of Jetty Marsh.

images.title: David Smith / Teigngrace seen from Templer Way
images.caption: Teigngrace church on a lovely day from the trail

images.title: David Smith / Field of maize (Indian corn) by Templer Way
images.caption: Field of maize (Indian corn) by the Way

images.title: Trish Steel [CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)]
images.caption: Lake, Stover Country Park. Stover Lake, is artificial, founded by James Templer as a landscape feature when he took over the estate.

description: Follow the Templer Way from Haytor on Dartmoor to the seaport of Teignmouth via Newton Abbot. The walk includes a wooded section through Yarner Woods near the route start and also visits the delightful Stover Country Park. With 14 acres of woodland, heathland, grassland, lake and marsh and a substantial variety of wildlife it is a real highlight on the walk. Shortly after passing Newton Abbot you will join the River Teign for a beautiful waterside section that leads to the finish point at Teignmouth. The walk is named after the Templer family who constructed the Stover Canal and Tramway to transport granite from Haytor Quarry to the coast at Teignmouth.
